title: The Procrastination Gym: 90-Day Reps for an Unbreakable Focus
premise: What if procrastination wasn't a character flaw, but a muscle that's simply out of shape? This book reframes productivity as a physical training regimen, offering daily, bite-sized 'focus reps'—from 5-minute mental deadlifts to 15-minute creative sprints—designed to systematically strengthen your willpower and attention span. Readers don't just learn about productivity; they literally work out their distraction muscles until deep focus becomes an automatic, effortless state.
conflict: The central conflict is the reader's own neurological and habitual resistance to sustained effort, personified as 'The Drift'—a force of distraction, instant gratification, and mental fatigue. The battle is fought in the micro-moments of every day, with the exercises serving as the tools to win each small skirmish and ultimately reshape the brain's default pathways.
setting: The reader's daily environment (home office, commute, workspace) transformed into a personal training ground for the mind, across a modern 90-day timeline.
tone: Energetic, coach-like, and scientifically-grounded; mixing the motivational punch of a personal trainer with the practical clarity of a physical therapy plan.
